title-group.article-title: Role of C-Reactive Protein Velocity in the Diagnosis of Early Bacterial Infections in Children After Cardiac Surgery

article-meta.aff: 1Pediatric Critical Care Unit, Schneider Children’s Medical Center of Israel, Petach Tikva, Israel
2Sackler Faculty of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel
3Pediatric Cardiac Care Unit, and Pediatric Infectious Disease unit, Schneider Children’s Medical Center of Israel, Petach Tikva, Israel

author-notes.corresp: Elhanan Nahum, Schneider Children’s Medical Center of Israel, Pediatric Critical Care Unit, 14 Kaplan St., Petach Tikva 49202, Israel. Email: enahum@clalit.org.il

abstract.p: Received November 20, 2009, Received Revised August 18, 2010, Submitted August 19, 2010 Fever after cardiac surgery in children may be due to bacterial infection or noninfectious origin like systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) secondary to bypass procedure. A marker to distinguish bacterial from nonbacterial fever in these conditions is clinically important. The purpose of our study was to evaluate, in the early postcardiac surgery period, whether serial measurement of C-reactive protein (CRP) and its change over time (CRP velocity) can assist in detecting bacterial infection. A series of consecutive children who underwent cardiac surgery with bypass were tested for serum levels of CRP at several points up to 5 days postoperatively and during febrile episodes (>38.0°C). Findings were compared among febrile patients with proven bacterial infection (FWI group; sepsis, pneumonia, urinary tract infection, deep wound infection), febrile patients without bacterial infection (FNI group), and patients without fever (NF group). In all, 121 children were enrolled in the study, 31 in the FWI group, 42 in the FNI group, and 48 patients in the NF group. Ages ranged from 4 days to 17.8 years (median 19.0, mean 46 ± 56 months). There was no significant difference among the groups in mean CRP level before surgery, 1 hour, and 18 hours after. A highly significant interaction was found in the change in CRP over time by FWI group compared with FNI group (P < .001). Mean CRP velocity ([fCRP – 18hCRP]/[fever time (days) – 0.75 day]) was significantly higher in the infectious group (4.0 ± 4.2 mg/dL per d) than in the fever-only group (0.60 ± 1.6 mg/dL per d; P < .001). A CRP velocity of 4 mg/dL per d had a positive predictive value (PPV) of 85.7% for bacterial infection with 95.2% specificity. Serial measurements of CRP/CRP velocity after cardiac surgery in children may assist clinicians in differentiating postoperative fever due to bacterial infection from fever due to noninfectious origin.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cardiac surgery with extracorporeal circulation often evokes a systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).1–3 Fever is the main symptom, and intervention is usually not necessary. However, sometimes fever following cardiac surgery is a sign of early bacterial infection4 warranting antibiotic therapy.

Researchers have long sought a marker to reliably identify serious bacterial infection and sepsis in children.5–7 Arkader et al8 found that in children after cardiac surgery, procalcitonin (PCT) levels successfully distinguished between sepsis and SIRS. Similar findings were noted by Falcoz et al.9 A recent review by Sponholz et al10 concluded that the dynamic change in PCT levels can be used as a tool for the diagnosis of postoperative bacterial complications in adults. However, data on the behavior of PCT in children after cardiac surgery are still sparse. Furthermore, the test for PCT is costly, and it is not available for routine use in most hospitals. Indeed, PCT is rarely, if ever, tested on a daily basis for follow-up.

Another, more available, marker that has been intensively investigated is C-reactive protein (CRP). Shaoul et al11 found that CRP levels were a better tool than white blood cell count or absolute neutrophil count in detecting bacteremia in children. Similar results were found in septic neonates and oncology patients.12,13 However, it has long been recognized that after cardiac surgery, the levels of CRP rise as part of the inflammatory response evoked by the bypass machine, and its dynamics have been delineated in the past.14 This factor complicates the use of CRP as a marker for infection in this setting. Sierra et al,15 in a study on 125 adult patients found that CRP can be an early indicator of bacterial infection in patients with SIRS. Similar results were reported by Rey et al,16 who found in a study on 94 pediatric patients that CRP was useful in diagnosing bacterial sepsis in children admitted to intensive care unit (ICU) with SIRS. To our knowledge, there are no studies on the role of CRP and its dynamic in the detection of early bacterial infection in pediatric cardiac surgery patients.

The aim of the present study was to investigate whether CRP velocity (rate of the change in CRP from the morning after surgery to fever day) can distinguish early bacterial infection during the first 5 days postoperation from noninfectious fever after cardiac surgery.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A prospective case-controlled study was conducted in the cardiac ICU of a major tertiary pediatric medical center. The protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board, and informed consent was obtained by the patients’ parents or legal guardians.

All consecutive children aged 1 day to 18 years who underwent cardiac surgery with bypass were eligible for the study. Patients who had fever during the 72 hours prior to surgery or were under a treatment course with antibiotic at the time of surgery were excluded from the study. Demographic and diagnosis and operative data (bypass time, aortic cross-clamp time, core temperature, etc) were collected for all patients.
All patients received prophylactic 40 mg/kg intravenous cefazolin 1 hour before surgical incision and another 3 doses postoperatively.

The study designed for 2 years, to enroll 540 patients in order to achieve a power of 0.9 and significance above .05, with a known total 8% rate of bacterial infection (early, first 5 days postoperation, and late, after the fifth day postoperation) in our institution. All patients with serious bacterial infection were included in the study, patients with fever but without bacterial infection, and their consecutive patients, without fever as the control group.

Significant infection, during the first 5 days after surgery, was defined as body temperature >38°C accompanied with positive blood or urine cultures for bacteria or fungal organisms, pneumonia, or deep wound infection. Pneumonia was defined as body temperature >38°C, with localized findings of crepitations or bronchial breath sounds on auscultation, localized lung infiltrate on chest x-ray film, and positive sputum cultures. Deep wound infection was defined by local erythema, wound discharge, positive cultures from discharge.

All febrile episodes with infection were reviewed and agreed as a true infection by 3 authors of the study (1 infectious disease expert and 2 pediatric intensive care physicians) were included in the analysis.

Blood samples for CRP measurement were obtained on the day before surgery, immediately on arrival to the ICU from the operating room (1 hour postoperatively), the morning after surgery (18 hours), on day 5 after surgery, and during febrile episodes. C-reactive protein levels were measured immediately by an immunoturbid assay using an Olympus AU640 analyzer (Olympus UK Ltd, Watford, United Kingdom). C-reactive protein velocity (the average rate change of CRP from the morning postoperation [18hCRP] to the CRP measured at fever time [fCRP], divided by the time period between the 2 measurements) was calculated according to the following formula:

Efficiency was calculated as ([true positive + true negative]/[true positive + true negative + false positive + false negative]) × 100.

Statistical analysis was done using BMDP (BMDP Statistical Software [1993], chief editor: W.J. Dixon, University of California press, Louisiana). Continuous variables were compared across groups using analysis of variance (ANOVA). The Mann-Whitney nonparametric U test was used for comparison between 2 groups with small numbers. Analysis of variance with repeated measures was used to determine the effect of time on change in CRP. Logistic regression was used to predict the risk of bacterial infection. A P value of ≤.05 was considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Over 22 months, 647 patients were eligible for inclusion in the study. Of them, 31 children had early serious bacterial infection, 42 patients with early fever but without bacterial infection, and 48 children without fever.

A total of 121 patients, 68 male and 53 female, were enrolled in the study. Ages ranged from 4 days to 17.8 years (median 19.0 and mean 46 ± 56 months). Average weight was 15.0 ± 15.3 kg. Table 1 describes the operative details.

Of the 121 patients, 31 patients had proven bacterial infection (FWI group; bloodstream infection in 17, pneumonia plus positive sputum cultures in 10, and deep wound infection with positive cultures from the discharge in 4); 42 patients had fever without bacterial infection (FNI group); and 48 patients had no fever (NF group), as a control group. There were no statistically significant differences among the groups in age, weight, bypass and aortic cross-clamp time, cooling temperature, or severity score. Mean operative time was significantly longer in the infectious group (211 ± 112 minute) than in both the nonfebrile patients (128 ± 58 minute; P < .01) and the fever-only patients (140 ± 68 min; P < .01).

The mean CRP levels at the various time points by group are shown in Table 2 . There was no significant difference among the groups in mean CRP level before surgery or at 1 hour and 18 hours after surgery. Comparison of the change in CRP over time yielded a highly significant interaction between the fever + infection group compared to the fever-only group (P < .001; Table 2).

caption.p: C-Reactive Protein Levels at the Various Time Points in Patients Without Fever, Patients With Fever Only, and Patients With Fever and Infection

fn.p: Abbreviations: CRP = C-reactive protein; NS = not significant.
a There was a highly significant interaction between the groups (fever only and fever with infection) and increase in CRP on day of fever.

sec.p: Mean CRP velocity was significantly higher in the children with fever and bacterial infection than in the children with fever only (4.00 ± 4.20 and 0.59 ± 1.6 mg/dL per d, respectively; P < .001). The positive and negative predictive values (NPVs) for various cutoffs of CRP velocity are presented in Table 3 . A CRP velocity of 4 mg/dL per d had a positive predictive value (PPV) of 85.7%, NPV of 69%, and 95.2% specificity for bacterial infection.

caption.p: Positive and Negative Predictive Values for Infection for Different Cutoffs of CRP Velocity

fn.p: Abbreviations: CRP = C-reactive protein; NPV = negative predictive value; PPV = positive predictive value.

sec.p: Subgroup analyses showed CRP velocity of 4.0 ± 4.8 mg/dL per d in the group with fever and bacteremia, compared to 3.2 ± 2.8 mg/dL per d in the group with fever and pneumonia (P = .85). Detailed site, day of infection, and CRP level of the infected cohort appears in Table 4 .

caption.p: C-Reactive Protein Velocity of Patients With Bacteremia and Pneumonia After Cardiac Surgery

tr.td: Day of fever postoperation, mean ± SD
CRP (mg/dL) at fever day, mean ± SD

sec.p: On logistic regression analysis to predict the risk of bacterial infection, CRP on the day of fever was significantly associated with bacterial infection (odds ratio [OR] 1.17, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.07-1.28). The area under the curve (AUC) of the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) plot was found to be 0.77.
All the children with severe bacterial infection survived.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our study shows that in children undergoing cardiac surgery, values of serum CRP measured immediately after surgery followed by daily measurements in the first 5 postoperative days can assist clinicians in differentiating early bacterial infection from other causes such as bypass-induced systemic inflammatory response. In the present series, the difference in CRP velocity ([fCRP – 18hCRP]/[fever time (days) – 0.75 (day)] between children with fever and serious bacterial infection and fever without infection was statistically significant (P < .001). Furthermore, there was a highly significant interaction in the change in CRP over time by presence of bacterial infection (P < .001).

C-reactive protein analysis comparing subgroup of patients with bacteremia and patients with bacterial pneumonia revealed no statistically significant difference in CRP velocity between the 2 groups, reflecting a similar CRP response to both infections in children after cardiac surgery.

C-reactive protein is an acute phase reactant used as a marker for infection since the early 1950s. A substantial number of studies in children have shown CRP to serve as a reliable predictor of bacterial infection17–21 and a means of identifying true bacteremia.11 In pediatric oncology patients, CRP was successfully used to detect fungal and bacterial infection, and its combination with other markers yielded an improvement in diagnostic performance.22,23 However, children undergoing cardiac surgery pose a dilemma because serum CRP frequently increases as part of the inflammatory response to the bypass procedure.24–27 Because the increase occurs several days after surgery, it may mask an infection-induced change, making this finding difficult to interpret. Macrina et al,28 in a study of 32 adult patients scheduled for coronary artery bypass surgery, found that CRP was not a reliable predictor of complications in this setting. However, the complications they investigated included low cardiac output syndrome and need for reoperation and aortic balloon; no attention was addressed to infection. In the only study in children to date, Aronen29 reported significantly higher levels of CRP in the patients who had postoperative complications than in those who did not. Yet, only 54 of the 78 patients with complications had suspected, but not definitive, bacterial infections: 2 had pericarditis, 1 pleurisy, 11 unspecified lower respiratory tract infection, and 9 “other conditions”—all clearly nonspecific diseases of either bacterial or nonbacterial etiology. The author also did not specify the time of occurrence of infection relative to the operation, which is crucial when using CRP as a marker.

The idea of evaluating the change over time of acute phase reactant was raised by Sponholz et al10 in a systematic review of PCT as a diagnostic tool for infection. They concluded that the dynamics of PCT levels, rather than the absolute values, could be important in identifying patients with bacterial infection after cardiac surgery. The postulated rational is that in the presence of already “primed,” by the cardiac bypass, immune system, and already elevated acute phase reactants, the additional infectious trigger will be more easi to detect in the change over time rather than the absolute level of the acute phase reactant.

To date, there is only 1 study, by Paran et al,30 which studied CRP velocity. In their study, they found that patients presenting to emergency room with febrile illness and bacterial infection had significantly higher CRP velocity, 3.61 mg/L per h, comparing to patients with nonbacterial febrile illness who had a CRP velocity of 0.41 mg/L per h. Similar results are demonstrated in our study, yet with lower CRP velocity (when corrected to mg/L per h). The lower CRP velocity in our study can be explained by the fact that Paran et al studied the CRP velocity in previously nontriggered immune system, while our patients had an already existing cytokine storm due to the bypass and operation procedures. Another possible explanation is that in Paran’s study, the exact starting time of infection is not always known, while in our study the starting point is clear. In both studies, Paran et al30 and ours, the AUC of the ROC was similar, 0.78 and 0.77, respectively. Similar results were reported by Kofoed et al31 with AUC of 0.81 for CRP and 0.88 for composite 6-marker (CRP, PCT, neutrophil count, soluble urokinase-type plasminogen activator, soluble triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells, and macrophage migration inhibitory factor) test, in a study done on 96 patients with bacterial infection. Although the AUC is superior in this study, most of these tests are unavailable on a daily basis, therefore their clinical relevance is relatively low.

In our study, we used 18-hour postoperation CRP as a starting reference value since postcardiac surgery patients at this time will not be infected yet the increase in CRP as a response to the bypass will be already expressed.

The present study is important in that not only did we compare post bypass febrile children with and without bacterial infection, but we also limited the time frame to the early postoperative period. We found that the serial measurement of CRP and CRP velocity, in the first 5 days, after pediatric cardiac surgery, may help clinicians differentiate postoperative fever due to bacterial infection from fever due to SIRS. Our analysis of the PPV and NPV showed CRP to be a handy bedside tool for assisting clinicians in deciding on the treatment of children with fever after cardiac surgery. Although a cutoff of CRP velocity of 4 mg/dL per d has a PPV of 85.7%, its moderate, 69% NPV, indicating substantial number of patients that may be missed using CRP velocity only.

C-reactive protein/CRP velocity should not serve as the sole tool for this purpose, and it should be combined with other clinical and laboratory data and good clinical judgment. We recommend that further studies be conducted to corroborate our findings and to evaluate other potential markers of bacterial infection, such as cytokines, in this patient population.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: This article is dedicated to the memory of Dr Yaffa Orbach who, despite her serious illness, assisted us greatly in conducting this study and sadly passed away before its publication.

fn.p: The authors declared no conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
The authors received no financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article.
